definition:
Let $X$ be a topological space. A [**partition of unity**]{} is a
collection of continuous functions
$\{\varepsilon_i \colon X \to [0,1]\}$ such that
$$\sum_i \varepsilon_i(x) = 1 \quad\mbox{for all $x \in X$}.$$

A partition of unity is [**locally finite**]{} if each $x$ in $X$ is
contained in an open set on which only a finite number of
$\varepsilon_i$ are non-zero. That is, if the cover
$\{\varepsilon_i^{-1}((0,1])\}$ is locally finite.

A partition of unity is [**subordinate to an open cover**]{} $\{U_i\}$
of $X$ if each $\varepsilon_i$ is zero on the complement of $U_i$.

A partition of unity for ${\mathbb{S}}^1$ is given by
$\{ \sin^2(\theta/2), \cos^2(\theta/2) \}$ subordinate to the covering
$\{ (0, 2\pi), (-\pi, \pi) \}$.

**Application to integration**

Let $M$ be an orientable manifold with volume form $\omega$ and a
partition of unity $\{\varepsilon_i(x)\}$. Then, the integral of a
function $f(x)$ over $M$ is given by
$$\int_M f(x) \omega = \sum_i \int_{U_i} \varepsilon_i(x) f(x) \omega.$$
It is of the choice of partition of unity.
